Why everyone should want to be a boss

21 Mar 2024 | 3 min read | Read story in medium ‚Üó
leadership career management business

I was recently invited to take the lead of the team I work with. Our boss had served his time and, being the programmer with most seniority, I was naturally set to step up. I gladly accepted the challenge.

Here are some reasons I can think: Photo by Ryoji Iwata on Unsplash

1. Knowing how to lead will make you better at following

There‚Äôs a stereotype that we as techies feel our work is the only real work, and managers don‚Äôt actually do much. This is patently false: most leaders work overtime and make hard decisions constantly, on top of being responsible for the work of their team. In a similar note, we often shy away from our leaders. We enjoy a bout of uninterrupted work, but we dislike meetings, especially the ‚ÄúHow is the task going?‚Äù type.

I think this applies to everyone‚Äôs relationship with their boss, but somehow having more important people as your boss makes it more unavoidable.

As Jocko Willink would say: take a step back, look at the big picture. Having a leader‚Äôs perspective means you get to think beyond the immediate. This is why leaders most times isolate themselves physically, in different offices, not because they feel superior, but to detach from the day-to-day.

4. Leading will teach you about yourself

You don‚Äôt know who you are until you lead others. If nothing else, this is a great opportunity for personal development. You get the chance to take the reins of a team working on something you know and love. This is a unique opportunity to practice being an adult.

Lastly, you can always step down

After this experience as tech lead, I will probably go back to software development because I love programming. But, who knows, the future might yet surprise us.
